trans-unit.source: Understanding the Table Service Data Model
trans-unit.target: Understanding the Table Service Data Model

trans-unit.source: The Table service offers structured storage in the form of tables.
trans-unit.target: The Table service offers structured storage in the form of tables.

trans-unit.source: The following sections outline the Table service data model.
trans-unit.target: The following sections outline the Table service data model.

trans-unit.source: Storage Account
trans-unit.target: Storage Account

trans-unit.source: A storage account is a globally unique entity within the storage system.
trans-unit.target: A storage account is a globally unique entity within the storage system.

trans-unit.source: The storage account is the parent namespace for the Table service, and is the basis for authentication.
trans-unit.target: The storage account is the parent namespace for the Table service, and is the basis for authentication.

trans-unit.source: You can create any number of tables within a given storage account, as long as each table is uniquely named.
trans-unit.target: You can create any number of tables within a given storage account, as long as each table is uniquely named.

trans-unit.source: The storage account must always be specified in the request URI.
trans-unit.target: The storage account must always be specified in the request URI.

trans-unit.source: The base URI for accessing the Table service is as follows:
trans-unit.target: The base URI for accessing the Table service is as follows:

trans-unit.source: Tables, Entities, and Properties
trans-unit.target: Tables, Entities, and Properties

trans-unit.source: Tables store data as collections of entities.
trans-unit.target: Tables store data as collections of entities.

trans-unit.source: Entities are similar to rows.
trans-unit.target: Entities are similar to rows.

trans-unit.source: An entity has a primary key and a set of properties.
trans-unit.target: An entity has a primary key and a set of properties.

trans-unit.source: A property is a name, typed-value pair, similar to a column.
trans-unit.target: A property is a name, typed-value pair, similar to a column.

trans-unit.source: The Table service does not enforce any schema for tables, so two entities in the same table may have different sets of properties.
trans-unit.target: The Table service does not enforce any schema for tables, so two entities in the same table may have different sets of properties.

trans-unit.source: Developers may choose to enforce a schema on the client side.
trans-unit.target: Developers may choose to enforce a schema on the client side.

trans-unit.source: A table may contain any number of entities.
trans-unit.target: A table may contain any number of entities.

trans-unit.source: Table Names
trans-unit.target: Table Names

trans-unit.source: Table names must conform to these rules:
trans-unit.target: Table names must conform to these rules:

trans-unit.source: Table names must be unique within an account.
trans-unit.target: Table names must be unique within an account.

trans-unit.source: Table names may contain only alphanumeric characters.
trans-unit.target: Table names may contain only alphanumeric characters.

trans-unit.source: Table names cannot begin with a numeric character.
trans-unit.target: Table names cannot begin with a numeric character.

trans-unit.source: Table names are case-insensitive.
trans-unit.target: Table names are case-insensitive.

trans-unit.source: Table names must be from 3 to 63 characters long.
trans-unit.target: Table names must be from 3 to 63 characters long.

trans-unit.source: Some table names are reserved, including "tables".
trans-unit.target: Some table names are reserved, including "tables".

trans-unit.source: Attempting to create a table with a reserved table name returns error code 404 (Bad Request).
trans-unit.target: Attempting to create a table with a reserved table name returns error code 404 (Bad Request).

trans-unit.source: These rules are also described by the regular expression "^[A-Za-z][A-Za-z0-9]{2,62}$".
trans-unit.target: These rules are also described by the regular expression "^[A-Za-z][A-Za-z0-9]{2,62}$".

trans-unit.source: Table names preserve the case with which they were created, but are case-insensitive when used.
trans-unit.target: Table names preserve the case with which they were created, but are case-insensitive when used.

trans-unit.source: Property Names
trans-unit.target: Property Names

trans-unit.source: Property names are case-sensitive strings up to 255 characters in size.
trans-unit.target: Property names are case-sensitive strings up to 255 characters in size.

trans-unit.source: Property names should follow naming rules for <externalLink><linkText>C# identifiers</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=155321</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: Property names should follow naming rules for <externalLink><linkText>C# identifiers</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=155321</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Some C# identifiers are not valid according to the <externalLink><linkText>XML specification</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=155322</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: Some C# identifiers are not valid according to the <externalLink><linkText>XML specification</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=155322</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: These identifiers may not be used in property names, because property names are sent via an XML payload in a request against the Table service.
trans-unit.target: These identifiers may not be used in property names, because property names are sent via an XML payload in a request against the Table service.

trans-unit.source: Property names are passed to the Table service within a URL.
trans-unit.target: Property names are passed to the Table service within a URL.

trans-unit.source: Certain characters must be percent-encoded to appear in a URL, using UTF-8 (preferred) or MBCS.
trans-unit.target: Certain characters must be percent-encoded to appear in a URL, using UTF-8 (preferred) or MBCS.

trans-unit.source: This encoding occurs automatically when you use the Azure .NET Libraries or construct a <codeEntityReference autoUpgrade="true" qualifyHint="false">T:System.Uri</codeEntityReference> object that includes a property name.
trans-unit.target: This encoding occurs automatically when you use the Azure .NET Libraries or construct a <codeEntityReference autoUpgrade="true" qualifyHint="false">T:System.Uri</codeEntityReference> object that includes a property name.

trans-unit.source: However, there are certain characters that are not valid in URL paths even when encoded.
trans-unit.target: However, there are certain characters that are not valid in URL paths even when encoded.

trans-unit.source: These characters cannot appear in property names.
trans-unit.target: These characters cannot appear in property names.

trans-unit.source: Code points like \uE000, while valid in NTFS filenames, are not valid Unicode characters, so they cannot be used.
trans-unit.target: Code points like \uE000, while valid in NTFS filenames, are not valid Unicode characters, so they cannot be used.

trans-unit.source: In addition, some ASCII or Unicode characters, like control characters (0x00 to 0x1F, \u0081, etc.), are also not allowed.
trans-unit.target: In addition, some ASCII or Unicode characters, like control characters (0x00 to 0x1F, \u0081, etc.), are also not allowed.

trans-unit.source: For rules governing Unicode strings in HTTP/1.1 see:
trans-unit.target: For rules governing Unicode strings in HTTP/1.1 see:

trans-unit.source: RFC 2616, Section 2.2: Basic Rules
trans-unit.target: RFC 2616, Section 2.2: Basic Rules

trans-unit.source: RFC 3987
trans-unit.target: RFC 3987

trans-unit.source: Beginning with version 2009-04-14, the Table service no longer supports including the dash (-) character in property names.
trans-unit.target: Beginning with version 2009-04-14, the Table service no longer supports including the dash (-) character in property names.

trans-unit.source: Property Limitations
trans-unit.target: Property Limitations

trans-unit.source: An entity can have up to 255 properties, including 3 system properties described in the following section.
trans-unit.target: An entity can have up to 255 properties, including 3 system properties described in the following section.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, the user may include up to 252 custom properties, in addition to the 3 system properties.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, the user may include up to 252 custom properties, in addition to the 3 system properties.

trans-unit.source: The combined size of all data in an entity's properties cannot exceed 1 MB.
trans-unit.target: The combined size of all data in an entity's properties cannot exceed 1 MB.

trans-unit.source: System Properties
trans-unit.target: System Properties

trans-unit.source: An entity always has the following system properties:
trans-unit.target: An entity always has the following system properties:

trans-unit.source: <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property
trans-unit.target: <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property

trans-unit.source: <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property
trans-unit.target: <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property

trans-unit.source: <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property
trans-unit.target: <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property

trans-unit.source: These system properties are automatically included for every entity in a table.
trans-unit.target: These system properties are automatically included for every entity in a table.

trans-unit.source: The names of these properties are reserved and cannot be changed.
trans-unit.target: The names of these properties are reserved and cannot be changed.

trans-unit.source: The developer is responsible for inserting and updating the values of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> and <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>.
trans-unit.target: The developer is responsible for inserting and updating the values of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> and <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>.

trans-unit.source: The server manages the value of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, which cannot be modified.
trans-unit.target: The server manages the value of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, which cannot be modified.

trans-unit.source: Characters Disallowed in Key Fields
trans-unit.target: Characters Disallowed in Key Fields

trans-unit.source: The following characters are not allowed in values for the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> and <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> properties:
trans-unit.target: The following characters are not allowed in values for the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> and <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> properties:

trans-unit.source: The forward slash (/) character
trans-unit.target: The forward slash (/) character

trans-unit.source: The backslash (\) character
trans-unit.target: The backslash (\) character

trans-unit.source: The number sign (#) character
trans-unit.target: The number sign (#) character

trans-unit.source: The question mark (?) character
trans-unit.target: The question mark (?) character

trans-unit.source: Control characters from U+0000 to U+001F, including:
trans-unit.target: Control characters from U+0000 to U+001F, including:

trans-unit.source: The horizontal tab (\t) character
trans-unit.target: The horizontal tab (\t) character

trans-unit.source: The linefeed (\n) character
trans-unit.target: The linefeed (\n) character

trans-unit.source: The carriage return (\r) character
trans-unit.target: The carriage return (\r) character

trans-unit.source: Control characters from U+007F to U+009F
trans-unit.target: Control characters from U+007F to U+009F

trans-unit.source: PartitionKey Property
trans-unit.target: PartitionKey Property

trans-unit.source: Tables are partitioned to support load balancing across storage nodes.
trans-unit.target: Tables are partitioned to support load balancing across storage nodes.

trans-unit.source: A table's entities are organized by partition.
trans-unit.target: A table's entities are organized by partition.

trans-unit.source: A partition is a consecutive range of entities possessing the same partition key value.
trans-unit.target: A partition is a consecutive range of entities possessing the same partition key value.

trans-unit.source: The partition key is a unique identifier for the partition within a given table, specified by the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property.
trans-unit.target: The partition key is a unique identifier for the partition within a given table, specified by the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property.

trans-unit.source: The partition key forms the first part of an entity's primary key.
trans-unit.target: The partition key forms the first part of an entity's primary key.

trans-unit.source: The partition key may be a string value up to 1 KB in size.
trans-unit.target: The partition key may be a string value up to 1 KB in size.

trans-unit.source: You must include the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property in every insert, update, and delete operation.
trans-unit.target: You must include the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property in every insert, update, and delete operation.

trans-unit.source: RowKey Property
trans-unit.target: RowKey Property

trans-unit.source: The second part of the primary key is the row key, specified by the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property.
trans-unit.target: The second part of the primary key is the row key, specified by the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property.

trans-unit.source: The row key is a unique identifier for an entity within a given partition.
trans-unit.target: The row key is a unique identifier for an entity within a given partition.

trans-unit.source: Together the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> and <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> uniquely identify every entity within a table.
trans-unit.target: Together the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PartitionKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> and <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> uniquely identify every entity within a table.

trans-unit.source: The row key is a string value that may be up to 1 KB in size.
trans-unit.target: The row key is a string value that may be up to 1 KB in size.

trans-unit.source: You must include the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property in every insert, update, and delete operation.
trans-unit.target: You must include the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RowKey</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property in every insert, update, and delete operation.

trans-unit.source: Timestamp Property
trans-unit.target: Timestamp Property

trans-unit.source: The <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property is a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DateTime</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> value that is maintained on the server side to record the time an entity was last modified.
trans-unit.target: The <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property is a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DateTime</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> value that is maintained on the server side to record the time an entity was last modified.

trans-unit.source: The Table service uses the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property internally to provide optimistic concurrency.
trans-unit.target: The Table service uses the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> property internally to provide optimistic concurrency.

trans-unit.source: The value of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is a monotonically increasing value, meaning that each time the entity is modified, the value of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> increases for that entity.
trans-unit.target: The value of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is a monotonically increasing value, meaning that each time the entity is modified, the value of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Timestamp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> increases for that entity.

trans-unit.source: This property should not be set on insert or update operations (the value will be ignored).
trans-unit.target: This property should not be set on insert or update operations (the value will be ignored).

trans-unit.source: Property Types
trans-unit.target: Property Types

trans-unit.source: The Table service supports a subset of data types defined by the <externalLink><linkText>OData Protocol Specification</linkText><linkUri>http://www.odata.org/</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: The Table service supports a subset of data types defined by the <externalLink><linkText>OData Protocol Specification</linkText><linkUri>http://www.odata.org/</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows the supported property types for the Table service:
trans-unit.target: The following table shows the supported property types for the Table service:

trans-unit.source: OData Data Type
trans-unit.target: OData Data Type

trans-unit.source: Common Language Runtime type
trans-unit.target: Common Language Runtime type

trans-unit.source: Details
trans-unit.target: Details

trans-unit.source: An array of bytes up to 64 KB in size.
trans-unit.target: An array of bytes up to 64 KB in size.

trans-unit.source: A Boolean value.
trans-unit.target: A Boolean value.

trans-unit.source: A 64-bit value expressed as Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).
trans-unit.target: A 64-bit value expressed as Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

trans-unit.source: The supported <languageKeyword>DateTime</languageKeyword> range begins from 12:00 midnight, January 1, 1601 A.D. (C.E.), UTC.
trans-unit.target: The supported <languageKeyword>DateTime</languageKeyword> range begins from 12:00 midnight, January 1, 1601 A.D. (C.E.), UTC.

trans-unit.source: The range ends at December 31, 9999.
trans-unit.target: The range ends at December 31, 9999.

trans-unit.source: A 64-bit floating point value.
trans-unit.target: A 64-bit floating point value.

trans-unit.source: A 128-bit globally unique identifier.
trans-unit.target: A 128-bit globally unique identifier.

trans-unit.source: <languageKeyword>Int32</languageKeyword> or <languageKeyword>int</languageKeyword>
trans-unit.target: <languageKeyword>Int32</languageKeyword> or <languageKeyword>int</languageKeyword>

trans-unit.source: A 32-bit integer.
trans-unit.target: A 32-bit integer.

trans-unit.source: <languageKeyword>Int64</languageKeyword> or <languageKeyword>long</languageKeyword>
trans-unit.target: <languageKeyword>Int64</languageKeyword> or <languageKeyword>long</languageKeyword>

trans-unit.source: A 64-bit integer.
trans-unit.target: A 64-bit integer.

trans-unit.source: A UTF-16-encoded value.
trans-unit.target: A UTF-16-encoded value.

trans-unit.source: String values may be up to 64 KB in size.
trans-unit.target: String values may be up to 64 KB in size.

trans-unit.source: By default a property is created as type <languageKeyword>String</languageKeyword>, unless you specify a different type.
trans-unit.target: By default a property is created as type <languageKeyword>String</languageKeyword>, unless you specify a different type.

trans-unit.source: To explicitly type a property, specify its data type by using the appropriate OData data type for an <link xlink:href="9ca046aa-e9b4-4eaf-a7c0-d6ccdbaf48b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Insert Entity</link> or <link xlink:href="96a833e2-388c-460c-bfad-11e723c67d3f" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Update Entity</link> operation.
trans-unit.target: To explicitly type a property, specify its data type by using the appropriate OData data type for an <link xlink:href="9ca046aa-e9b4-4eaf-a7c0-d6ccdbaf48b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Insert Entity</link> or <link xlink:href="96a833e2-388c-460c-bfad-11e723c67d3f" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Update Entity</link> operation.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="8f029e46-f7c1-476a-b349-0649551aa127" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Inserting and Updating Entities</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="8f029e46-f7c1-476a-b349-0649551aa127" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Inserting and Updating Entities</link>.

trans-unit.source: For examples that show how to filter on the various property types in a query request URI, see <link xlink:href="74e73539-b624-4f47-8603-112cbb6780db" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Querying Tables and Entities</link>.
trans-unit.target: For examples that show how to filter on the various property types in a query request URI, see <link xlink:href="74e73539-b624-4f47-8603-112cbb6780db" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Querying Tables and Entities</link>.

trans-unit.source: Get Started with Table Storage
trans-unit.target: Get Started with Table Storage
